events.title: Welcome to Multi-Asset Investing!
events.description: You've mastered SIP basics in Chapter 1. Now you have ₹1,00,000 to allocate and ₹25,000/month to invest. Your emergency fund (₹1,80,000) is already secured.

teachingMoment.explanation: Don't put all eggs in one basket! Diversification across asset classes reduces risk while maintaining returns. Different assets perform differently in various market conditions.
teachingMoment.tip: A common starting allocation: 60% Equity (40% Large Cap + 20% Mid Cap), 20% Gold, 20% FD/Debt

events.title: Understanding Asset Correlation
events.description: Assets that move differently (negative correlation) protect your portfolio during volatility.

teachingMoment.explanation: When stocks fall, gold often rises (negative correlation). FDs stay stable. This balance smoothens your returns over time.
teachingMoment.example: If equity drops 20%, but gold rises 15% and FD stays stable, your overall portfolio impact is minimal.

events.title: Initial Portfolio Allocation
events.description: You have ₹1,00,000 lumpsum + ₹25,000 monthly. How will you allocate?
events.recommendation: Balanced allocation provides optimal risk-return tradeoff

teachingMoment.explanation: Invest lumpsum in stable assets (FD, Gold) and do SIP in volatile assets (Equity) to average out market fluctuations.
teachingMoment.recommendation: Lumpsum: 50% FD + 50% Gold. SIP: 70% Equity (40% Large + 30% Mid) + 30% Gold

events.title: COVID Second Wave - Market Correction
events.description: Equity markets drop 6% on pandemic fears. Gold surges 4% as safe haven!

teachingMoment.explanation: See how gold is protecting your portfolio? While equities fell 6%, gold rose 4%. Your diversified portfolio dropped only ~2-3% instead of 6%!
teachingMoment.insight: This is the power of diversification. Pure equity investors lost 6%, but you lost much less.

events.title: Should You Rebalance?
events.description: Your target was 60% equity, 20% gold, 20% debt. Current allocation has drifted.

teachingMoment.explanation: Over time, winners grow and losers shrink, changing your asset allocation. Rebalancing means selling winners and buying losers to maintain target allocation.
teachingMoment.recommendation: Rebalance annually or when allocation drifts by 5-10%. For now, continue SIP as planned - it naturally rebalances.

questions.question: What is the primary benefit of diversification?
options: Reduces portfolio risk without necessarily sacrificing returns
questions.explanation: Diversification reduces portfolio risk by spreading investments across uncorrelated assets. When one falls, others may rise or stay stable, reducing overall volatility.

questions.question: What does negative correlation between assets mean?
options: When one asset goes up, the other tends to go down
questions.explanation: Negative correlation means assets move in opposite directions. Gold and equity often have negative correlation - when stocks fall, gold rises as a safe haven.

questions.question: When should you rebalance your portfolio?
options: Annually or when allocation drifts 5-10% from target
questions.explanation: Rebalance annually or when your allocation drifts significantly (5-10%) from targets. This locks in profits from winners and buys underperformers at lower prices.

questions.question: Why is gold included in a diversified portfolio?
options: As a hedge and portfolio stabilizer during equity downturns
questions.explanation: Gold acts as a hedge against inflation and equity volatility. It tends to rise when stocks fall (negative correlation), protecting your portfolio during corrections.

questions.question: What is the tax treatment for equity LTCG?
options: 10% on gains above ₹1 lakh after 1 year holding
questions.explanation: Equity long-term capital gains (held >1 year) are taxed at 10% on gains exceeding ₹1 lakh per year. First ₹1 lakh is tax-free.

questions.question: How long must you hold gold for LTCG benefits?
questions.explanation: Gold and debt funds must be held for 3+ years to qualify for long-term capital gains treatment (20% with indexation benefit).

questions.question: What should you do with a windfall/bonus?
options: Spend it all - you earned it!
Keep it all in savings account
questions.explanation: A balanced approach: invest 50% (often in underweight assets to rebalance), save 30% for goals, and enjoy 20%. This balances growth, planning, and lifestyle.

questions.question: During a market correction, what typically happens to gold?
options: Often rises as a safe haven
questions.explanation: Gold typically rises during equity corrections as investors seek safe havens. This negative correlation is why gold is valuable in diversified portfolios.

questions.question: What is rebalancing?
options: Selling winners and buying losers to maintain target allocation
Only buying more of winning assets
questions.explanation: Rebalancing means selling overweight assets (winners) and buying underweight assets (losers) to return to your target allocation, locking in profits and managing risk.

questions.question: What was the key lesson from surviving the correction in Month 42?
options: Diversification protected the portfolio - equity fell 10% but gold rose 6%
Should have invested only in gold
questions.explanation: The correction showed diversification in action: while equity fell 10%, gold surged 6%, so the diversified portfolio only dropped ~5%. Pure equity investors lost much more.

vsChapter1.conclusion: Similar returns with significantly less risk
